scholarships.name: Loran Award
scholarships.deadline_note: Deadline for the 2026 Loran Award cohort; typically mid-October each year.
scholarships.description_raw: Four-year leadership scholarship for outstanding Canadian students entering first undergraduate degree at a partner university. Includes annual stipend, matching tuition waiver, summer internships, mentorship and a leadership development program.
scholarships.eligibility_raw: Canadian citizens or permanent residents in their final year of high school or CEGEP, entering university in 2026. Minimum 85% average (or R score threshold in Quebec), strong character, service, and leadership. Tenable at partner universities only.
essay_prompts_raw: Describe a time when you took the initiative to address a need in your community. What did you do and what did you learn?
Reflect on a challenging moment that tested your values. How did you respond and how has it shaped the person you are today?

source.found_via: google search: Loran Award 2026 deadline October 16 2025
source.notes: Deadline and GPA from 2026 Loran Award FAQ and overview; award value from program description.

scholarships.name: Schulich Leader Scholarships
scholarships.deadline_note: Approximate 2026 nominee deadline; schools nominate and students then submit detailed application. Confirm exact dates each cycle.
scholarships.description_raw: Flagship Canadian STEM scholarship program for entrepreneurial-minded high school graduates entering STEM programs at partner universities. 100 scholarships annually: engineering awards valued at about $120,000 over four years and science/math awards valued at about $100,000.
scholarships.eligibility_raw: Canadian citizens or permanent residents in their final year of high school, planning full-time undergraduate studies in an eligible STEM program at a Canadian partner university. Strong academic performance, leadership, and entrepreneurial mindset. One nominee per high school plus possible additional regional nominations.
essay_prompts_raw: Describe a STEM-related project, initiative, or challenge where you demonstrated leadership or entrepreneurial thinking.
How do you hope to use your STEM education to create impact in Canada or globally?

source.found_via: google search: Schulich Leader Scholarships Canada STEM $120,000
source.notes: Award counts and values from program overview; typical timeline based on partner university pages for 2025–26.

scholarships.name: TD Scholarships for Community Leadership
scholarships.deadline_note: Closes mid-November 2025 for students entering post-secondary in 2026 (BigFuture shows 2025-11-15 for this cycle).
scholarships.description_raw: National scholarship recognizing Canadian students who have made outstanding, sustained contributions to their communities. Each scholarship is valued at up to $70,000 over four years, covering tuition and living expenses plus summer employment and mentorship with TD.
scholarships.eligibility_raw: Canadian citizens or permanent residents in their final year of high school (or CEGEP in Quebec) entering post-secondary full time. Strong, sustained community leadership and initiative are the primary criteria; solid academics required but no formal minimum GPA published.
essay_prompts_raw: Describe a community leadership initiative you led or co-led. Why was it important, what challenges did you face, and what impact did it have?
How will receiving this scholarship help you continue your community leadership and studies?

source.found_via: google search: TD Scholarships for Community Leadership 2025 deadline amount
source.notes: Number, value and structure from TD site and Scholarship Partners guide; close date aligned with 2025–26 listing.

scholarships.name: Terry Fox Humanitarian Award
scholarships.deadline_note: Applications (including references) due December 1 each year by midnight Pacific Time.
scholarships.description_raw: Humanitarian scholarship honouring the legacy of Terry Fox. Supports Canadian students who demonstrate courage, compassion, and commitment to voluntary humanitarian service, alongside solid academic performance and involvement in sport or fitness.
scholarships.eligibility_raw: Canadian citizens or permanent residents who have not yet completed their first undergraduate degree. Applicants must show significant, sustained humanitarian service and volunteerism, good academic standing, and involvement in sport or physical activity. Award is renewable for up to four years subject to continued eligibility.
essay_prompts_raw: Explain how your humanitarian or volunteer activities reflect the values embodied by Terry Fox.
Describe a significant obstacle you have faced and how it has shaped your commitment to helping others.

source.found_via: google search: Terry Fox Humanitarian Award amount deadline December 1
source.notes: Deadline and award value verified via program FAQs and partner scholarship listings.

scholarships.name: RBC Future Launch Scholarship for Indigenous Youth
scholarships.deadline_note: Typical closing date around early February (many 2025 guides list February 5 as deadline).
scholarships.description_raw: Scholarship for First Nations, Inuit and Métis students across Canada pursuing post-secondary education. Provides up to $10,000 per year for up to four years, plus mentoring and support to help students succeed in their studies and careers.
scholarships.eligibility_raw: First Nations, Inuit or Métis students in Canada, typically Canadian citizens or permanent residents. Must be pursuing or planning to pursue a 1–4 year program at a publicly funded Canadian post-secondary institution. Selection considers academic achievement, financial need, community involvement and leadership.
essay_prompts_raw: Describe your connection to your Indigenous community and how it influences your goals for education and leadership.
How will this scholarship help you contribute to your community or advance Indigenous knowledge and perspectives in your field?

source.found_via: google search: RBC Future Launch Scholarship for Indigenous Youth 20 scholarships up to $10,000
source.notes: Award amount and counts from multiple university scholarship pages and 2025 guidance PDFs; deadline approximate based on 2025 cycle.

scholarships.name: RBC Future Launch Scholarship
scholarships.deadline_note: Many 2025 school guides list December 31 as a deadline window; program typically runs several intakes per year.
scholarships.description_raw: Skills-focused scholarship for Canadian youth aged 15–29 with a clear vision for their future. Awards $1,500 (one-time) that can be used for courses, workshops, equipment, or other learning opportunities, not just traditional degrees.
scholarships.eligibility_raw: Canadian citizens or permanent residents aged 15–29, not employed by RBC or immediate family of an employee. Can be in school, working, or unemployed. Applicants describe their goals and how funds will help them gain future skills. Financial need and barriers to education are considered.
essay_prompts_raw: What skills or experiences do you want to gain in the next year, and how will this scholarship help you get there?
Describe a challenge you have faced in pursuing education or training and how you are working to overcome it.

source.found_via: google search: RBC Future Launch Scholarship 15–29 500 scholarships $1500
source.notes: Award size and approximate number of scholarships from RBC site and 2025 scholarship guides; some schools list Dec 31, 2025 as a key deadline.

scholarships.name: Horatio Alger Canadian Scholarship Program
scholarships.deadline_note: 2025–26 cycle typically open Dec 1 to March 15.
scholarships.description_raw: Scholarship for Canadian students who have faced and overcome significant adversity, demonstrate financial need, and show strong academic potential. Provides $10,000 toward undergraduate studies at any accredited Canadian post-secondary institution.
scholarships.eligibility_raw: Canadian citizens or permanent residents in their final year of high school with plans to enter full-time post-secondary studies in Canada. Must demonstrate critical financial need (family income below an association threshold), strong academic performance, and a record of integrity and perseverance in overcoming personal challenges.
essay_prompts_raw: Describe a significant challenge or adversity you have faced. How did you respond, and what did you learn about yourself?
Explain your educational and career goals and how this scholarship will help you achieve them given your financial circumstances.

source.found_via: google search: Horatio Alger Canadian Scholarship Program 160 scholarships March 15 2026
source.notes: Award amount and number from association and 2025 Canadian school scholarship pages.

scholarships.name: McDonald's HACER National Scholarship
scholarships.deadline_note: Many listings show November 30, 2025 as the deadline; program sometimes extends deadlines in specific years.
scholarships.description_raw: National scholarship supporting high-achieving students who have contributed to or been impacted by the Latino community in the United States. Awards range up to $100,000 in total funding per recipient towards undergraduate study.
scholarships.eligibility_raw: U.S. high school seniors planning full-time enrollment at an accredited institution. Minimum 2.8 GPA on a 4.0 scale. U.S. citizens, permanent residents or DACA recipients. Selection considers academic achievement, financial need, personal character, and contributions to the Latino community.
essay_prompts_raw: Describe your connection to the Latino community and how you have contributed to it.
Explain your educational and career goals and how this scholarship will help you make an impact.

source.found_via: google search: McDonald's HACER National Scholarship up to 100000 November 30 2025
source.notes: Eligibility and GPA from scholarship explainers; amount and approximate deadline from Unigo and major scholarship blogs.

scholarships.name: University of Toronto National Scholarship Program
scholarships.deadline_note: For 2026 entry: school nomination deadline October 10, U of T admission deadline October 17, National Scholarship application deadline October 31, 2025.
scholarships.description_raw: U of T's most prestigious scholarship for Canadian high school students, recognizing original and creative thinkers, high academic achievers, and community leaders. Covers tuition, incidental and residence fees for up to four years, with additional benefits for finalists.
scholarships.eligibility_raw: Canadian citizen, permanent resident or protected person in final year of Canadian secondary school or first-year CEGEP. Must apply for admission to the University of Toronto and usually be nominated for the National Book Award (or self-identify as meeting criteria). Selection emphasizes outstanding academics, creativity, leadership and community involvement.
essay_prompts_raw: Discuss an idea, project, or question that has sparked your intellectual curiosity. How have you explored it beyond the classroom?
Describe a way you have contributed to your school or community and explain how this experience has shaped you.

source.found_via: google search: University of Toronto National Scholarship Program 2026 deadline October 31 2025
source.notes: Benefits and award count from U of T scholarship pages; 2025 deadlines from scholarship summary sites.

scholarships.name: University of Manitoba General Entrance Scholarships
scholarships.deadline_note: Students who apply for admission and submit transcripts by March 1 are automatically considered for general entrance scholarships.
scholarships.description_raw: Entrance scholarship program recognizing high school graduates entering the University of Manitoba. Awards are automatically offered based on admission averages, with amounts ranging from hundreds to several thousand dollars.
scholarships.eligibility_raw: New high school graduates applying for full-time first-year undergraduate studies at the University of Manitoba by the March 1 entrance deadline and meeting the required admission and grade thresholds. Awards are primarily merit-based and applied automatically; some additional entrance awards and bursaries require separate applications.

source.found_via: google search: University of Manitoba general entrance scholarships March 1 2025
source.notes: Entrance award description from UM financial aid pages and third-party scholarship listings; amounts and count based on General Entrance Scholarships summary.

scholarships.name: The Gates Scholarship
scholarships.deadline_note: Deadline for 2025–26 cycle is September 15, 2025 at 2:00 PM PT; confirm exact date/time each year.
scholarships.description_raw: The Gates Scholarship (TGS) is a highly selective last-dollar scholarship for outstanding Pell-eligible minority high school seniors. It covers the full cost of attendance not met by other aid for up to five years and includes extensive scholar support, mentoring, and leadership development.
scholarships.eligibility_raw: Applicants must be Pell-eligible, low-income US citizens or permanent residents from specific underrepresented minority groups, be high school seniors with at least a 3.3 weighted GPA on a 4.0 scale, and plan to enroll full-time in a four-year degree at a US not-for-profit college or university. Strong leadership, community service, and academic excellence are expected.
essay_prompts_raw: Describe a significant challenge you have faced as a student from a low-income background and how you grew from the experience.
How have you demonstrated leadership and service in your school or community?
Explain your long-term academic and career goals and how this scholarship would help you achieve them.
Reflect on a time you made a positive impact on others and what you learned about yourself.

source.found_via: search: "The Gates Scholarship" eligibility GPA deadline
source.notes: Last-dollar scholarship for Pell-eligible minority students; award often approximated as up to $160,000 over a degree. Deadline and GPA pulled from current fact sheet and partner sites.

scholarships.name: Coca-Cola Scholars Program Scholarship
scholarships.deadline_note: For the 2025–26 cycle, the Phase 1 application closes September 30, 2025 at 5:00 PM ET; confirm annually.
scholarships.description_raw: The Coca-Cola Scholars Program is an achievement-based scholarship recognizing high school seniors who demonstrate outstanding leadership, academic excellence, and a sustained commitment to service. Selected Scholars receive a $20,000 scholarship plus access to a powerful alumni network and leadership development opportunities.
scholarships.eligibility_raw: Applicants must be current high school or home-schooled seniors in the US (including DC, Puerto Rico, and select DoD schools), hold eligible US citizenship or residency status, plan to enroll full-time at an accredited US postsecondary institution, and have at least a 3.0 unweighted GPA. Children or grandchildren of Coca-Cola employees and certain affiliates are ineligible.
essay_prompts_raw: As a semifinalist, reflect on a leadership experience where you created meaningful change in your school or community.
Describe a service project or initiative that best represents your commitment to improving the lives of others.
Share how your background and experiences have shaped your goals and the type of leader you hope to become.

source.found_via: search: "Coca-Cola Scholars Program" eligibility GPA deadline 2025
source.notes: Official site plus recent 2025–26 cycle guides used for deadlines, amount, and 3.0 GPA requirement. Application is multi-phase with essays and an interview for later stages.

scholarships.name: Point Foundation Flagship Scholarship
scholarships.deadline_note: Recent cycle lists a November 20, 2025 deadline; confirm on the Point Foundation site each year.
scholarships.description_raw: The Point Foundation Flagship Scholarship supports LGBTQ+ and ally students pursuing undergraduate, graduate, or professional degrees at accredited US institutions. Scholars receive multi-year financial support, leadership development, mentoring, and access to a national community of LGBTQ+ leaders.
scholarships.eligibility_raw: Applicants must identify as LGBTQ+ or as committed allies, plan full-time enrollment in an accredited US degree program, demonstrate financial need, strong academic achievement (typically 3.3+ GPA), and a record of leadership and community involvement, particularly in LGBTQ+ communities.
essay_prompts_raw: Describe your journey as an LGBTQ+ person or ally and how it has shaped your leadership and advocacy.
How have you contributed to the LGBTQ+ community, and what impact do you hope to have in the future?
Explain your educational and career goals and how the Point Foundation community would help you achieve them.

source.found_via: search: "Point Foundation Flagship Scholarship" eligibility GPA deadline
source.notes: Amount varies by need; $12,000 and 5 awards figure taken from recent scholarship aggregators. GPA and deadline based on current 2025–26 cycle info.

scholarships.name: TheDream.US National Scholarship
scholarships.deadline_note: Recent school counselor materials list late February (around Feb 21) deadlines; confirm the exact deadline per cycle on the official site.
scholarships.description_raw: TheDream.US National Scholarship provides significant last-dollar funding for DREAMers who want to earn a bachelor’s or associate degree at one of the program’s Partner Colleges. It covers a substantial portion of tuition and fees and may include a stipend for books and supplies.
scholarships.eligibility_raw: Applicants must be undocumented immigrant students (with or without DACA/TPS) who came to the US before a specified cutoff date and age, have continuously lived in the US, have a minimum high school GPA of about 2.5, demonstrate significant unmet financial need, and plan to enroll full-time at a National Partner College.
essay_prompts_raw: Share your immigration story and how it has shaped your dreams and educational goals.
Describe a challenge you have faced as an undocumented or DACA/TPS student and how you responded.
How will earning a degree at a Partner College help you support your family and community?

source.found_via: search: "The Dream.US National Scholarship" amount deadline 33000
source.notes: Amounts up to $16,500 (associate) and $33,000 (bachelor’s) from recent scholarship summaries. Deadline varies year to year; counselor documents for 2025–26 mention late February.

scholarships.name: Amazon Future Engineer Scholarship
scholarships.deadline_note: Placeholder mid-January 2025 date for demo; the program typically closes in January—confirm the exact deadline on the official scholarship portal each cycle.
scholarships.description_raw: The Amazon Future Engineer Scholarship offers up to $40,000 in college funding (up to $10,000 per year) plus a paid summer internship at Amazon for high school seniors from underserved and underrepresented communities who plan to study computer science or a closely related field.
scholarships.eligibility_raw: Applicants are US high school seniors from low-to-moderate-income households who have taken or are currently enrolled in a computer science course, hold US citizenship or permanent residency, meet a minimum GPA requirement around 2.3, and plan to pursue a CS-related major full-time at an accredited US college or university.
essay_prompts_raw: Describe how your experiences have shaped your interest in computer science and technology.
How have you contributed to your community, and how do you hope to use technology to create positive change?
Explain why financial support and the Amazon Future Engineer community are important for your journey.

source.found_via: search: "Amazon Future Engineer Scholarship" up to $40,000 2025
source.notes: Amount and number of awards based on scholarship provider and news coverage for the 2025 cohort. Exact deadline varies by year; date here is a tagged placeholder for app demo.

scholarships.name: Microsoft Tuition Scholarship
scholarships.deadline_note: Approximate early-February 2025 date; Microsoft announces specific deadlines each cycle—confirm on the official scholarship page.
scholarships.description_raw: The Microsoft Tuition Scholarship provides partial or full tuition support for one academic year to undergraduate students pursuing computer science, computer engineering, or related technical fields at universities in the United States, Canada, or Mexico.
scholarships.eligibility_raw: Applicants must be enrolled full-time in a bachelor’s degree program at a four-year college or university in the US, Canada, or Mexico, pursuing a technical major such as computer science or computer engineering, and maintain a strong academic record (around 3.0/4.0 or higher). Selection emphasizes academic excellence, passion for technology, and demonstrated leadership or impact.
essay_prompts_raw: Describe a technical project or experience that best illustrates your passion for computer science or engineering.
How have you demonstrated leadership or impact in your academic, professional, or community experiences?
Explain how a Microsoft scholarship would support your academic and career goals in technology.

source.found_via: search: "Microsoft Tuition Scholarship" eligibility 3.0 GPA US Canada Mexico
source.notes: Covers partial or full tuition for one year; exact award amount and number of recipients vary by cycle. Deadline here is approximate for demo and should be re-confirmed.

scholarships.name: Mike Rowe WORKS Work Ethic Scholarship Program
scholarships.deadline_note: For the 2025–26 year, official materials list an April 17, 2025 deadline; some outreach articles mention slightly different close dates—verify on mikeroweworks.org.
scholarships.description_raw: The Work Ethic Scholarship Program helps people who want to learn a skilled trade and are willing to work hard. The foundation awards millions of dollars in scholarships for training programs in trades like welding, plumbing, electrical work, HVAC, and more.
scholarships.eligibility_raw: Applicants must plan to enroll in an approved trade program, sign the S.W.E.A.T. Pledge, answer questions about work ethic, create a video, provide two references from a teacher or employer, verify school costs, and submit transcripts and tax information. The program is focused on work ethic, personal responsibility, and commitment to a trade career.
essay_prompts_raw: What does work ethic mean to you, and how have you demonstrated it in your life so far?
Why do you want to pursue a skilled trade instead of (or in addition to) a traditional four-year degree?
Describe a time you took personal responsibility for a difficult situation and what you learned from it.

source.found_via: search: "Mike Rowe WORKS Work Ethic Scholarship" 2025 deadline program details
source.notes: Program total funding around $1–2.5M with varying award sizes; deadline and required steps (S.W.E.A.T. pledge, video, references, transcripts, tax form) from 2025 cycle announcements.

scholarships.name: Generation Google Scholarship (North America)
scholarships.deadline_note: For the 2025–26 cycle, external calls list an August 14, 2025 deadline; confirm on Google’s official scholarship page.
scholarships.description_raw: Generation Google Scholarship (North America) supports students pursuing computer science or closely related degrees in the US and Canada. It aims to help students from historically underrepresented groups in tech become leaders in the field.
scholarships.eligibility_raw: Applicants must intend to be enrolled full-time in a computer science, computer engineering, or closely related program at an accredited institution in the US or Canada. They should demonstrate strong academic performance, financial need, and a commitment to diversity, equity, and inclusion in technology—often as members of groups underrepresented in tech.
essay_prompts_raw: Describe a time when you worked to improve inclusion or equity in your community, school, or in technology.
How have your experiences shaped your identity and your interest in computer science?
What are your career goals in technology, and how will you support others from underrepresented backgrounds as you progress?

source.found_via: search: "Generation Google Scholarship 2025-2026 North America $10,000"
source.notes: Award amount ($10,000 USD / $5,000 CAD) and August 14, 2025 deadline taken from current cycle announcements and university scholarship pages.

scholarships.name: Google Lime Scholarship
scholarships.deadline_note: Recent university postings mention April 21 closing dates for Lime/Google cycles; confirm the specific 2025 deadline on Lime Connect’s site.
scholarships.description_raw: The Google Lime Scholarship supports students with disabilities who are pursuing degrees in computer science or closely related fields at universities in the US or Canada. Scholars receive funding plus an invitation to a Google Scholars’ Retreat and may be considered for internships.
scholarships.eligibility_raw: Applicants must have or consider themselves to have a visible or invisible disability, be enrolled as undergraduate or graduate students in the US or Canada, plan to study computer science or a closely related field full-time, maintain a strong academic record, and demonstrate passion for computer science and leadership in the disability and tech communities.
essay_prompts_raw: Describe how your disability has influenced your perspective and your path in computer science.
How have you advocated for accessibility or inclusion in your school, workplace, or community?
What impact do you hope to have in technology as a disabled technologist or ally?

source.found_via: search: "Google Lime Scholarship" 10,000 USD 5,000 CAD deadline
source.notes: Award values derived from university and scholarship listings; some sites list 2025 and 2026 cycles with early-spring deadlines. Number of awards (~13) based on recent Google/Lime program descriptions.

scholarships.name: Women Techmakers Scholars Program (Anita Borg Memorial)
scholarships.deadline_note: Historic program data for 2018–2019 shows a December 6 deadline; the program has since evolved—treat this as a legacy example and confirm any current WTM scholarship details.
scholarships.description_raw: The Women Techmakers Scholars Program (formerly the Google Anita Borg Memorial Scholarship) supported women studying computer science and related technical fields. Scholars received funding plus participation in a retreat and global Women Techmakers community, with emphasis on leadership and impact.
scholarships.eligibility_raw: Applicants identified as women, were enrolled or intending to enroll in accredited undergraduate, master’s, or PhD programs in computer science, computer engineering, informatics, or related fields, showed strong academic performance, and demonstrated leadership and impact in their communities and in advancing gender equity in technology.
essay_prompts_raw: Describe your contributions to advancing gender equity or inclusion in technology.
How have you demonstrated leadership in your academic, professional, or community work?
Tell us about a technical project or experience that best represents your interests and goals in computing.

source.found_via: search: "Women Techmakers Scholars Program formerly Google Anita Borg" 10,000 USD
source.notes: Program details mainly from 2017–2019 cycle documentation; kept here as a rich, legacy example of a selective women-in-tech scholarship. Status and structure may differ today.

scholarships.name: Rhodes Scholarship (Global)
scholarships.deadline_note: Global Rhodes Scholarship applications typically close around 31 July; exact dates and constituency deadlines vary and must be confirmed each year.
scholarships.description_raw: The Rhodes Scholarship is a fully funded postgraduate award supporting exceptional students from around the world to study at the University of Oxford. It covers Oxford course fees and provides an annual stipend for living expenses, with funding normally for two years and the possibility of a third depending on the degree programme.
scholarships.eligibility_raw: Applicants must meet constituency-specific eligibility criteria, including age limits (typically 18–23, with a later upper bound for some routes), completion or near-completion of an undergraduate degree with outstanding academic performance, and a high standard of English. Candidates are selected on academic excellence, energy to use their talents fully, courage and devotion to duty, moral force of character, and instincts to lead and serve others. Application processes vary by country or constituency and usually require institutional endorsement for some routes.
essay_prompts_raw: Write a personal statement that explains your academic interests, key formative experiences, and why study at Oxford as a Rhodes Scholar aligns with your long-term contribution to the world.
Describe a time when you showed moral courage or stood up for a principle in the face of difficulty. What did you learn about yourself?
Discuss how you have used your talents in service of others and how you intend to continue that service in your future leadership.

source.found_via: search: "Rhodes Scholarship eligibility stipend 2025 global deadline"
source.notes: Stipend level (~£20,400/year) and coverage of Oxford course fees from Rhodes Trust site; global deadline of 31 July 2025 referenced for the Global Scholarship route; age ranges and selection criteria summarised from official eligibility pages and Canadian constituency guidance. Amount range approximates total value over a typical two-year course including fees and stipend.

scholarships.name: Chevening Scholarship (UK Government)
scholarships.deadline_note: Many 2026–27 Chevening calls list early-October deadlines (for example, 7 October 2025 in recent regional calls); applicants must check the official Chevening website for exact dates.
scholarships.description_raw: Chevening Scholarships are fully funded one-year master’s awards for emerging leaders from Chevening-eligible countries to study any subject at a UK university. The scholarship typically covers full tuition fees, a monthly living stipend, travel to and from the UK, visa costs, and additional allowances, and provides access to a global leadership and alumni network.
scholarships.eligibility_raw: Applicants must be citizens of a Chevening-eligible country or territory, have completed an undergraduate degree equivalent to at least an upper second-class honours in the UK, and have at least two years of work experience. They must apply to three eligible UK master’s programmes, receive an unconditional offer from at least one, and commit to return to their home country for a minimum period (normally two years) after the award. Chevening seeks candidates with strong academic potential, leadership and networking skills, and a clear vision for how they will create positive change.
essay_prompts_raw: Describe how you have demonstrated leadership and influence in your professional or community life. What was the context, what actions did you take, and what was the impact?
Chevening is about building global networks. Explain how you build and maintain professional relationships and how you would use the Chevening community in your future plans.
Outline your short- and long-term career goals, why you chose your three UK courses, and how studying in the UK with Chevening will help you contribute to your home country.
Reflect on a significant challenge you have faced and how it has shaped your values, decision-making, and approach to public or community impact.

source.found_via: search: "Chevening Scholarship 2025 eligibility stipend fully funded"
source.notes: Coverage (tuition, stipend, flights, visa, allowances) summarised from Chevening FAQ and external guidance; stipend examples around £1,347/month for 2024–25 used as reference for award range. Typical deadlines in early October confirmed via recent Chevening calls and regional initiatives.

scholarships.name: Erasmus Mundus Joint Masters Scholarship
scholarships.provider_name: European Education and Culture Executive Agency (EACEA)
scholarships.deadline_note: Each Erasmus Mundus Joint Master sets its own application and scholarship deadlines; 8 January 2026 is a typical example used by several EMJMs. Applicants must check the specific consortium website.
scholarships.description_raw: Erasmus Mundus Joint Masters (EMJM) are high-level integrated master’s programmes delivered by international consortia of universities. Competitive EU-funded scholarships are available to top-ranked applicants worldwide, usually covering participation costs (including tuition), a monthly living allowance, and contributions to travel and visa costs for one to two years of study across at least two European countries.
scholarships.eligibility_raw: Applicants must hold a bachelor’s degree (first degree) or be in their final year and graduate before the EMJM starts, or demonstrate equivalent learning recognised by the awarding country. Students from any country can apply. Selection is merit-based and managed by each EMJM consortium, often considering academic excellence, motivation for the specific programme, letters of reference, language proficiency, and fit with the programme’s thematic focus.
essay_prompts_raw: Explain why you are applying to this specific Erasmus Mundus Joint Master and how its international structure fits your academic and career goals.
Describe a previous academic or professional experience that prepared you for intensive study and mobility across multiple countries.
Reflect on how you will contribute to and benefit from the multicultural cohort and partner institutions in this programme.

source.found_via: search: "Erasmus Mundus Joint Masters scholarship 1,400 EUR per month participation costs"
source.notes: Funding model (scholarships cover participation costs plus monthly allowance and travel) summarised from Erasmus+ official pages; 1,400 EUR/month maximum and up to 24 months referenced from EMJM organisational guidance. Deadline example based on current EM programmes such as GLOCAL.

scholarships.name: DAAD Helmut-Schmidt-Programme (Master’s Scholarships for Public Policy and Good Governance)
scholarships.deadline_note: Helmut-Schmidt applications typically close in late July for admission in the following year; exact dates vary by call and must be confirmed in the current DAAD announcement.
scholarships.description_raw: The DAAD Helmut-Schmidt-Programme supports future leaders from developing and emerging countries to study selected master’s programmes in public policy, governance, law, economics, and administration at German universities. The scholarship includes a monthly stipend, full tuition waiver, health insurance, travel allowance, study and research grants, and a preparatory German language course, with a strong focus on good governance, democracy, and social justice in the scholars’ home countries.
scholarships.eligibility_raw: Applicants must be citizens of eligible countries in Africa, Latin America, Asia, and parts of Europe, hold a first academic degree in the social sciences, political science, law, economics, public policy, or related fields, and typically have relevant professional or volunteer experience. They should demonstrate strong motivation for public service, a commitment to good governance and democratic values, and the intention to contribute actively to social and political development in their home countries. Financial need and limited access to higher education opportunities are taken into account.
essay_prompts_raw: Explain a governance or public policy challenge in your home country and how advanced training in Germany would help you address it.
Describe your professional or civic experience related to public policy, administration, or social justice and its impact on your community.
Outline your long-term plans for contributing to good governance and democratic development after completing this master’s degree.

source.found_via: search: "DAAD Helmut-Schmidt-Programme stipend tuition waiver 992 euros"
source.notes: Programme description, focus on public policy and good governance, and stipend level (~992 EUR/month) summarised from DAAD scholarship database and current call PDFs. Coverage (tuition waiver, health insurance, language course, travel and study grants) taken from recent 2025 announcement summaries.

scholarships.name: Vanier Canada Graduate Scholarships (Vanier CGS)
scholarships.deadline_note: Institutions set internal nomination deadlines (often in September) ahead of the federal deadline in late October or early November; check the current Vanier cycle instructions.
scholarships.description_raw: The Vanier Canada Graduate Scholarships program helps Canadian institutions attract and retain world-class doctoral students. Valued at $50,000 per year for up to three years, Vanier CGS supports PhD and combined graduate research programs across health, natural sciences and engineering, and social sciences and humanities. Selection is based on academic excellence, research potential, and leadership, each weighted equally.
scholarships.eligibility_raw: Applicants must be nominated by a Canadian institution with a Vanier quota, be pursuing their first doctoral degree (including eligible joint programs with a significant research component), and have completed no more than a specified number of months of doctoral study by a fixed date in the competition year. They must demonstrate a high standard of academic achievement, a strong research record or potential, and notable leadership contributions in academic and community contexts. Detailed GPA thresholds and internal deadlines are set by institutions and agencies.
essay_prompts_raw: Provide your research proposal for the doctoral work to be supported by the Vanier CGS, including objectives, significance, and methodology.
Describe your previous research contributions and how they demonstrate your potential as a leading researcher in your field.
Explain your leadership contributions inside and outside academia and how they position you to mobilize knowledge and create broader impact.

source.found_via: search: "Vanier Canada Graduate Scholarship $50,000 per year 3 years eligibility"
source.notes: Value ($50,000/year for up to three years) and number of awards (~166 annually) summarised from Vanier and Canadian university pages. Note that in 2025 the program is being harmonized with other federal doctoral scholarships; kept here as a representative high-profile PhD award.

scholarships.name: Pierre Elliott Trudeau Foundation Doctoral Scholarship
scholarships.deadline_note: For the 2026 scholar competition, applications open 9 September 2025 and close 17 November 2025 at 16:00 ET; dates are set annually by the Foundation.
scholarships.description_raw: The Pierre Elliott Trudeau Foundation Doctoral Scholarship is a three-year leadership programme for doctoral candidates in the social sciences and humanities who are engaging with themes related to human rights and dignity, responsible citizenship, Canada and the world, or people and their natural environment. Scholars receive substantial funding for tuition and living costs plus an annual allowance for research and language-learning activities, alongside intensive leadership training and mentorship.
scholarships.eligibility_raw: Applicants must be enrolled in or accepted to a full-time doctoral program (or combined MA/PhD) in the social sciences or humanities at a Canadian university, or Canadians pursuing such study abroad. They should have completed or be in their first or second year of doctoral study in the competition year. Candidates must demonstrate outstanding academic achievement, leadership and engagement in communities, and a strong fit with the Foundation’s themes and leadership curriculum. Both Canadian and international students may be eligible under specific conditions outlined by the Foundation.
essay_prompts_raw: Describe your doctoral research project, how it relates to one or more of the Foundation’s themes, and why it matters for society.
Tell a story about a concrete moment when you exercised leadership or took a stand in your community. What did you learn about yourself and others?
Explain how the Foundation’s leadership programme, cohort model, and mentorship network would shape your development as an engaged scholar-leader.

source.found_via: search: "Pierre Elliott Trudeau Foundation Doctoral Scholarship $50,000 per year allowance 2025"
source.notes: Value (up to $50,000/year stipend plus up to $20,000/year allowance for three years) summarised from Foundation FAQs and Canadian university pages; 2026 competition dates (Sept 9–Nov 17, 2025) taken from 2025 announcements.

scholarships.name: Fulbright Foreign Student Program
scholarships.provider_name: U.S. Department of State – Bureau of Educational and Cultural Affairs
scholarships.deadline_note: Application deadlines are set by each participating country and typically fall between May and June, with application portals opening around February for many countries.
scholarships.description_raw: The Fulbright Foreign Student Program enables graduate students, young professionals, and artists from over 160 countries to study or conduct research in the United States. Awards are generally fully funded and can cover tuition, living stipend, travel, health benefits, and other expenses. The program emphasises academic merit, cultural exchange, and potential for leadership and mutual understanding.
scholarships.eligibility_raw: Eligibility varies by country and is administered by national Fulbright Commissions or U.S. Embassies. In general, applicants must reside in their country of citizenship at the time of application, hold at least the equivalent of a U.S. bachelor’s degree with strong academic performance, be proficient in English, and not hold U.S. citizenship. Each country may specify additional field priorities, funding details, and timelines. Applicants compete for nomination in their home country and then for placement at U.S. institutions.
essay_prompts_raw: Describe your proposed field of study or research in the United States and how it will contribute to your academic and professional goals.
Explain how you have engaged in your community or profession and how participation in the Fulbright Program would allow you to deepen your contributions.
Discuss how you will help promote mutual understanding between your home country and the United States during and after your grant.

source.found_via: search: "Fulbright Foreign Student Program benefits eligibility 2025"
source.notes: Programme overview and approximate number of awards (~4,000) drawn from Fulbright foreign student site and U.S. university descriptions. Benefits (tuition, stipend, airfare, health plan, visa support) summarised from official and regional Fulbright pages; deadlines noted as varying by country with applications typically due May–June.

scholarships.name: Commonwealth Shared Scholarship
scholarships.provider_name: Commonwealth Scholarship Commission in the UK (CSC)
scholarships.deadline_note: University and CSC pages for the 2026–27 entry list scholarship application deadlines around 9 December 2025 at 16:00 GMT; exact timelines and eligible courses depend on the partner university.
scholarships.description_raw: Commonwealth Shared Scholarships are for candidates from eligible low- and middle-income Commonwealth countries to study selected one-year taught master’s courses at UK universities. The awards are co-funded by the UK’s Foreign, Commonwealth and Development Office and participating universities, and usually cover full tuition fees, approved airfare, a living allowance, and additional allowances.
scholarships.eligibility_raw: Applicants must be citizens of, or have been granted refugee status by, an eligible Commonwealth country and be permanently resident in such a country. They must be available to start academic studies in the UK by the beginning of the relevant academic year, hold at least an upper second-class honours degree (or equivalent), and be unable to afford study in the UK without the scholarship. Eligible master’s programmes are in development-related fields aligned with CSC development themes (such as science and technology for development, health systems, prosperity, governance, crisis response, and inclusion). Applications are submitted both to the university and via the CSC online system.
essay_prompts_raw: Describe how your chosen master’s course relates to one of the Commonwealth Scholarship Commission’s development themes and the needs of your home country.
Explain your financial circumstances and why you would be unable to study in the UK without this scholarship.
Outline your plans to apply the skills and knowledge gained in the UK to contribute to development in your country or region after graduation.

source.found_via: search: "Commonwealth Shared Scholarship eligibility 2:1 honours financial need deadline December 2025"
source.notes: Eligibility (citizenship of eligible Commonwealth country, permanent residence, 2:1 or equivalent, financial need) summarised from CSC and partner university pages. Value description (fees, stipend, flights, allowances) drawn from multiple UK university scholarship pages for the Shared scheme. Deadline example 9 December 2025 from SOAS and other listings.

scholarships.name: Knight-Hennessy Scholars at Stanford University
scholarships.deadline_note: Knight-Hennessy application deadlines for the 2026 cohort fall in early October 2025, several weeks before most underlying Stanford program deadlines; exact dates are published each cycle.
scholarships.description_raw: Knight-Hennessy Scholars is a fully funded graduate scholarship at Stanford University for emerging global leaders across all disciplines. Scholars receive funding for up to three years of graduate study, including tuition, a stipend for living and academic expenses, and a travel grant for one annual trip to and from Stanford. The program includes a multidisciplinary leadership development curriculum and a diverse cohort intentionally selected from around the world.
scholarships.eligibility_raw: Applicants from any country may apply. They must also apply separately to and be admitted by a full-time Stanford graduate degree program. In general, applicants must have earned their first bachelor’s degree within a specified recent time window (for example, January 2018 through September 2025 for the 2026 cohort, with an extension for some military applicants). Selection emphasizes independence of thought, purposeful leadership, and a civic mindset, assessed through academic records, recommendations, essays, and a video or in-person assessment.
essay_prompts_raw: Describe the experiences and values that have most shaped your ambitions and the kind of leader you aspire to be.
Tell us about a time you pursued an unconventional path, challenged a prevailing view, or took a principled risk. What happened and what did you learn?
Explain how your proposed Stanford program and the Knight-Hennessy community together will help you create impact at scale.

source.found_via: search: "Knight-Hennessy Scholars funding covers tuition stipend travel eligibility any nationality"
source.notes: Funding details (tuition, stipend, travel, up to three years) summarised from Knight-Hennessy funding pages and U.S. university guidance. Eligibility (recent bachelor’s degree year window, open to all nationalities, co-application with Stanford program) summarised from official eligibility and criteria pages.

scholarships.name: Schwarzman Scholars Program
scholarships.deadline_note: For the class entering 2027–2028, global and U.S. applicant deadlines typically fall in early to mid-September of the previous year, with slightly different dates for Chinese passport holders; confirm exact deadlines each cycle.
scholarships.description_raw: Schwarzman Scholars is a fully funded one-year master’s program in Global Affairs at Tsinghua University in Beijing designed to prepare future leaders for roles in geopolitics, business, and civil society. The scholarship covers tuition and fees, room and board, travel to and from Beijing, in-country study tours, required course materials, and a stipend for personal expenses.
scholarships.eligibility_raw: Candidates must be between 18 and 28 or 29 years of age (depending on the entry year definition), have completed a bachelor’s degree before the program start date, and demonstrate strong English proficiency. Applicants from any country and academic background are welcome, though they must show outstanding academic achievement, leadership potential, and a record of initiative and impact. Separate application timelines and procedures exist for international applicants and for those holding passports from the People’s Republic of China.
essay_prompts_raw: Describe a leadership experience where you brought together people with different perspectives to address a complex challenge.
Explain how studying Global Affairs in China through the Schwarzman Scholars program fits into your long-term vision for impact.
Reflect on a moment that significantly changed how you view global issues, power, or cooperation.

source.found_via: search: "Schwarzman Scholars eligibility 18-28 years fully funded one year masters"
source.notes: Eligibility (age 18–28, bachelor’s before August 1, strong English) and funding coverage summarised from Schwarzman admissions and FAQ pages plus partner university descriptions. Deadline window derived from current 2026–27 application cycle timelines.

scholarships.name: Burger King McLamore Foundation Scholars Program (Canada)
scholarships.deadline_note: Confirmed deadline for the 2025 application cycle is December 15, 2025.
scholarships.description_raw: Provides scholarships to high school students in the U.S., Canada, and Puerto Rico who are entering post-secondary education and have demonstrated academic achievement and community involvement.
scholarships.eligibility_raw: Must be a high school senior (or equivalent) who plans to enroll full-time in an accredited US or Canadian post-secondary institution and have a minimum 2.5 GPA.
essay_prompts_raw: Topics focus on future goals, community involvement, and overcoming challenges.

source.found_via: google search: Burger King McLamore Foundation Scholars Program Canada deadline 2025
source.notes: Deadline confirmed for Dec 15, 2025.

scholarships.eligibility_raw: Must identify as Black or Indigenous (First Nations, Métis, or Inuit). Must be entering first year of an eligible undergraduate Engineering program at a partner institution (e.g., McMaster, McGill). Financial need demonstrated.
essay_prompts_raw: Personal statement focusing on background, career goals, and how the scholarship will help.

scholarships.eligibility_raw: Must be entering first year of full-time undergraduate study at an accredited Canadian college or university. Strong academic record and commitment to community service required.

scholarships.eligibility_raw: Must identify as Black, be enrolled full-time in a recognized Canadian post-secondary institution, and demonstrate financial need. Minimum GPA of 2.7 (or 70%).

scholarships.eligibility_raw: Must be entering first year of a post-secondary institution in an agriculture-related program. Must be from a rural Canadian community. Academic standing and leadership potential are assessed.

scholarships.description_raw: Non-repayable financial assistance provided by the federal government to eligible full-time and part-time students from low- and middle-income families, or those with dependents or disabilities.
scholarships.eligibility_raw: Eligibility depends on family income, number of dependents, and enrollment status (full-time/part-time) in an eligible post-secondary institution. Must be a Canadian citizen or permanent resident.

source.found_via: google search: Canada Student Grants maximum amount 2025

scholarships.eligibility_raw: Must be a female student entering an undergraduate program in Computer Science or a related STEM field at a partner Canadian university.

scholarships.eligibility_raw: Must be an Alberta resident and Canadian citizen/PR who has completed high school in Alberta with qualifying grades (typically 75-80%+ averages).

scholarships.name: Rotary Peace Fellowships
scholarships.deadline_note: Application deadline for 2026-2027 academic year is May 15, 2025.
scholarships.description_raw: Fully funds leaders around the world to earn a master's degree or certificate in peace and conflict resolution. Covers tuition, room, board, and travel.
scholarships.eligibility_raw: Must have three years of professional experience in peace or development work for the Master's program. Open to all countries. Must demonstrate leadership in peace work.
essay_prompts_raw: Multiple essays focusing on professional experience, commitment to peace, and leadership roles in conflict resolution.

source.found_via: google search: Rotary Peace Fellowship 2026 application deadline

scholarships.eligibility_raw: Must be enrolled full-time in a university/college/vocational school. Open to Canadian residents (age of majority).

scholarships.name: Western University National Scholarship Program
scholarships.deadline_note: The deadline to submit the application (including nomination) is February 14, 2025.
scholarships.description_raw: Recognizes all-round excellence. National Scholarships are awarded on the basis of outstanding academic performance, creative and innovative thought, and significant achievement in extracurricular activities.
scholarships.eligibility_raw: Canadian Citizens or Permanent Residents. Must be nominated by their school and have an admission average of 90% or higher.
essay_prompts_raw: Describe the academic interests and experiences that have most shaped you and how they have prepared you to contribute to the Western community.
Explain a creative or innovative project, initiative, or achievement that you are proud of. What problem were you trying to solve and what was the impact?
Discuss your most significant extracurricular or community engagement and how it demonstrates your leadership and commitment to others.

source.found_via: client-provided partial listing; common knowledge of Western National Scholarship structure

scholarships.name: Baker Hughes Indigenous STEM Scholarship
scholarships.deadline_note: Application packages must be received by May 31, 2025 for the 2025/2026 academic year.
scholarships.description_raw: Scholarship program intended to encourage Indigenous students to pursue higher education in STEM and trades fields, supporting energy industry diversity.
scholarships.eligibility_raw: Must identify as Indigenous (First Nations, Métis, Inuit) and be enrolled in an eligible STEM or Trades program.
essay_prompts_raw: Describe your educational and career goals in STEM or the trades and how they connect to your community.
Explain how your Indigenous identity and experiences have shaped your path toward the energy or technology sectors.
Share an example of how you have contributed to your community or served as a role model for other Indigenous youth.

scholarships.name: Enbridge Fueling Futures Scholarship Program
scholarships.deadline_note: General scholarship contests often close Oct 31, 2025. Partner university deadlines may vary.
scholarships.description_raw: Provides financial aid to students who are pursuing post-secondary education in fields relevant to the energy industry, with specific streams for Indigenous and diverse students.
scholarships.eligibility_raw: Must be enrolled in a university or college program in an eligible field (STEM, Trades, Business). Specific streams require Indigenous identity, female identity, or demonstrated financial need.
essay_prompts_raw: Describe your program of study and how it connects to the future of energy and sustainability in your community or region.

How would receiving this scholarship help you achieve your educational and career goals, particularly in relation to the energy sector?
